title: Fitting Generalized Linear Models with Abundance-Based Constraints (ABCs) — glmabc
text: default approach generalized linear regression categorical covariates reference group encoding (RGE): one category selected "reference group" categorical variable, results presented relative group. output inequitable can misleading, especially categorical covariates like race/ethnicity, gender identity, religion, national origin, etc. example, suppose analyst fits generalized linear model form y ~ x + race + x:race, x continuous covariate. model allows race-specific coefficients \(x\). However, RGE requires reference group, typically White (selected alphabetically), glm output presented relative group: (Intercept) refers intercept White group x refers coefficients \(x\) White group. remaining race-specific parameters presented differences relative White group. Clearly, output inequitable: elevates one group (White) others, presents group "normal" others "deviations normal". output also unclear: (Intercept) x effects refer reference (White) group nowhere mentioned default output. glmabc addresses issues. ABCs parametrize regression model main effect terms, (Intercept) x, averages race-specific terms. instance, coefficients \(x\) represent race-averaged effect \(x\), race-specific coefficients \(x\) represent deviations average, rather reference (White) group. notion "average" derives argument cprob: can input user (e.g., population proportions), otherwise set sample proportions group.

text: lmabc provides estimation inference linear regression categorical covariates (race, sex, etc.). Common strategies, including defaults lm, select "reference" group (e.g,. White, Male, etc.) present results relative group. Crucially, introduces biases inequities presentation results cases, statistical estimation . lmabc uses abundance-based constraints (ABCs) (1) fully eliminate biases, (2) provide appealing statistical properties related estimation invariance improved statistical power, (3) produce interpretable model output. lmabc reproduces core functionality lm includes functions generalized (logistic, Poisson, etc.) penalized (lasso, ridge, etc.) linear models.
